Author: Alex3917
Content:
Apropos of nothing, I'd like to throw out a longstanding personal idea for improving dating sites. All of the current dating sites work by matching similar interests. This is really dumb, because most people don't want to date people with the same interests; rather, they want to date people with any compelling set of interests as long as there aren't any red flags. So rather than matching people with similar interests, dating sites should let you add tags to your profile and then let show you everyone in your area except for those with tags you are filtering out.

For example, show me everyone within 10 miles of 14850 except those whose profiles contain: jesus, single mom, smoker, republican, pulp-free orange juice, george bush, herpes, bbw, us weekly, horses, etc.

Author: tak111
Title: Ask YC: How to get more beta testers?
Content: Hi, I am needing beta testers for my new application, but I am not sure where to get them. My targeted audience are senior high school kids and non CS college students. Does anyone have any idea?

Author: jacobolus
Content:
Your rant is rather silly, but if you'd like to know about the colon at the end of blocks:

http://mail.python.org/pipermail/python-list/2000-December/0...

http://mail.python.org/pipermail/python-list/2000-December/0...

If you really want a close block delimiter, python is happy to oblige. Just spell it `#end`. ;-)

Author: marvin
Content: The man behind the handle is probably Eliezer Yudkowsky, a researcher at SIAI who, among other things, run the annual Singularity Summit. In case anyone wants to know.

Author: langer
Content:
This reminds me of the first essay students hand in when they arrive at university. The tutor then proceeds to criticise the hell out of it.

Ironically, this particular post has an onomatopoeic ring to it - the content within the post is about as organised as the content being described.

That said - I'm curious to hear how everyone thinks these Tweet-aggregator startups are going to do. It seems like every other article on my KillerStartups.com RSS feed is in the space.

Author: aswanson
Content: I hope you guys challenge and win.  Search needs an upgrade these days.

Content: Yes, but the Harvard course’s treatment isn’t nearly as deep as MIT’s SICP course was, skipping most of the coolest parts, and they put it after a C course.

Author: JeffJenkins
Content: Information Rules is an excellent book going into details of how markets work in information economies where the marginal cost of a product is near-zero. It covers segmentation, lock-in, network effects, etc. ( http://www.amazon.com/dp/087584863X/ )

Author: michael_dorfman
Content: I don't think it's necessary to prove that the ideas suck; rather, it's enough (for me) to say that I don't find them compelling enough to invest the time and energy and commitment they would require to bring to fruition.  I believe that successful start-ups are based on ideas that the founders are actively jonesing over, not merely ideas that "don't suck."
